intro: Abies cephalonica var. arcadica, commonly known as the Arcadian fir, is a rare and endemic subspecies native to the mountainous regions of Greece. It is a coniferous evergreen tree characterized by its narrow, conical shape and dark green, needle-like foliage. The tree produces small, spherical cones that release seeds, contributing to its reproductive cycle. Its habitat is typically found in high-altitude forests with cool, moist climates. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.

It is commonly associated with mixed forests and grows on rocky or well-drained soils. The plant is adapted to temperate and subalpine environments, often occurring in association with other coniferous species. Its distribution is limited to specific geographic areas, reflecting its ecological requirements and historical range.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abies cephalonica var. arcadica was mainly introduced to ornamental horticulture and botanical gardens due to its unique appearance and cold hardiness.
